question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped be gain a foundation in key areas of chemistry, such as reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and atomic chemistry. I learned about reaction rates and how they are influenced by factors like temperature, concentration, and catalysts, and how to apply the rate laws to predict reaction behavior. In thermodynamics, I gained an understanding of concepts like enthalpy, entropy, and Gibbs free energy, which allowed me to analyze and predict the spontaneity of chemical reactions. Additionally, I strengthened my knowledge of atomic chemistry, including atomic structure, electron configurations, and periodic trends, which helped me understand chemical bonding and reactivity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I now understand the importance of using the various resources provided (office hours, problem solving sessions, practice exams, textbook) as they diversify the ways I understand and describe concepts so they can be more easily generalized. I learned how different areas of chemistry relate to each other (acid-base, kinetics, thermochemistry...) which helps me understand them in a real-world context and what approach I should use to answer different questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned in taking this course is the importance of rechecking one's work even if one is certain with their answer. Chemistry is very memorization and mathematics based meaning that it is inevitable that one may make a mistake. In units such as thermodynamics and integrated rate law/kinetics, the majority of our homework assignments were math based where we had to make conversions using stoichiometry or integrate algebra to find the quantity of a substance. In all, it is noted that chemistry is very tedious which made me become a much more meticulous student who ensured all her units, conversions, and math were done precisely. Another thing that I learned while taking this course is how there's a lot of intersectionality of different material into different courses. Again, chemistry is very math based which led to the usage for algebra and physics to complete assignments or understand new topics. It's fascinating to know that other subjects can be applied to subjects I learn, enhancing the level of interest I have for the subjects. Lastly, I learned the importance of working together. During the discussions, it was mandatory that we talk amongst our teammates to finish our assignments. In doing so, I was able to see my mistakes and correct them through the help of my group member.

response_text: What made this class stimulating was the level of excitement that Professor Anna Martinez always brought to the classroom each day. Furthermore, what I liked most about Professor Anna Martinez is that after finishing a problem on the board, she would look immediately look around the room to see if there were any questions from the students. That is the type of energy a welcoming classroom should have as that is what encourages students to stay curious and to reach out, especially if they need help understanding a practice problem.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Use the practice tests; First test is going to be really hard but do not get thrown off; I think this class definitely made me better at studying for tests and using all the resources provided to me

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is very hard. It is advertised as a 101 course but prior chem knowledge is almost required. If you do not have this prior knowledge, you have to work extremely hard to catch up with the pace of the class. Furthermore, if you have labs on certain sections of the week what you are learning in class will not align with lectures. This means that most weeks you are learning two entirely new topics, juggling discussions and exams on top of lecture (which are not recorded). Start progressively studying for exams, don't wait or it will catch up to you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is an interesting course that is considerable difficult that requires time and dedication. It is worth it to make sure you really understand the concepts each week and to do practice problems/tests before the exams.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Study hard in the beginning, do not cram, do every discussion question, and work with TAs/Dr. Martinez when you are confused on topics. Also, utiliza SAGE tutoring groups and peer tutors.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you ask questions when you are confused and maintain open communication with Dr. Martinez. Add to your cheat sheet after each lecture so you do not have to do it entirely when preparing for a midterm. Complete lab work early because it can be extremely tedious. Attend office hours with anyone (professor, any TA, director of chemistry undergraduate studies, lab director) when you need help or are seeking clarification.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Chemistry has a reputation of being very difficult and this especially holds true at Duke. That being said, this course is extremely doable if you put in the effort to stay on top of lecture content, do practice problems, and spend time on your labs. Personally, it took some time for me to figure out how to study for the course, so do not be discouraged if you face initial issues with adjusted to this course; it will all work out.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it! Chemistry 101 provides a strong foundation in fundamental chemistry concepts while also offering practical, hands-on experience through labs and problem-solving sessions. The material is challenging but rewarding, and the instructor does a great job of making complex topics accessible and engaging. You'll gain a deeper understanding of the world around you and develop critical thinking skills that will be useful in many areas. While it requires dedication and attention, the course is very rewarding, and you'll walk away with valuable knowledge and skills that you can apply beyond the classroom.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In Chemistry 101, I gained valuable knowledge and skills that enhanced my academic and personal growth. One major takeaway was learning how to approach studying effectively. By focusing on active recall, consistent review, and problem-solving practice, I developed strategies that improved my understanding and retention of complex material.Secondly, I learned foundational concepts of chemistry, such as the periodic trends and stoichiometry, which are essential for understanding chemical reactions and processes. These topics required me to think analytically and make connections between theoretical knowledge and practical application.Lastly, I developed a systematic approach to problem-solving. Through guided practice in the course, I now break down challenging problems into smaller, manageable steps, ensuring accuracy and thoroughness in my work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. We developed knowledge about molecular and atomic orbitals. We developed the skills of recognizing the difference between this two theories being that the molecular theory is more complex, not being a great fit for larger and complex molecules, yet it working great to look at molecules such as water into a deeper level because it might show some aspects the atomic orbital theory does not show because of its simplicity.
2. Another method developed was thermodynamics. Specifically, we learned about entropy, enthalpy, free energy, and how they interact and impact each other in a molecule. Free energy combines enthalpy and entropy into a single value by using and equation.
3. A last insight we develop was acid, base reactions and chemical equilibrium. I now know weak acids and bases are lower in energy than strong acids and bases, and because equilibrium favors the reaction side with the lowest-energy species, acid-base reactions will go to the side with the weakest acids and bases. The equilibrium of a reaction then favors the side with weaker acids and bases.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
It could allow students to ask more questions, or he could ask the students questions to make it more stimulating. Often half the class was asleep because it was just the professor talking the whole time. There was also very little interaction between the professor and the students in the class because of the large amount of students int he class. I would advise having more sections with less people. Additionally in a lecture this big, I would expect Parise to wear a mic, because in the back of the lecture hall it is extremely hard to hear, I have especially heard this from people who have hearing disabilities but also people with normal hearing. 
It would also be helpful for Parise to record lectures and post the lecture recordings and notes, because when you're sick it's extremely difficult to know what happened in class. IN class I'm very focused on trying to jot down all the notes rather than understanding what is being said. If notes are posted I can focus on understanding in lecture and then taking notes afterwards to cement the information in my brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was my gateway course to learning how to study efficiently to best prepare for exams in college. As an applied science, chemistry cannot be learned by memorization alone and requires significant practice in comprehending problems based on foundational concepts and understanding the purpose of the given information in solving for the answer. As a first-generation and low-income student, it was extremely difficult to catch up initially, especially given I had never been taught how to properly study for standardized exams from a Title I school. I managed to do progressively better in this course by doing lots of practice problems to reinforce key concepts, consistently attending lectures and office hours, and most of all, proactively seeking additional academic resources, such as learning consultations with ARC or SAGE Tutoring.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cox, Dr. Liu, and Dr. Martinez left a lot to be desired from this course. While I applaud the incredible work of the TAs to fill in the gaps in teaching and caring, this course instruction was well below my expectations. The professors exhibited an overwhelming lack of empathy and care for students, instead opting to increase workload and shame those struggling. I am particularly disappointed in their reaction to most students struggling on Exam 1, which initially had an average score in the low 50s. Rather than recognizing that group failure likely indicated poor teaching on their part, they chose to complain that we all weren't trying hard enough. They offered for us to take the exact same test with the exact same resources a second time, which would be an almost comedic example of trying the same thing and expecting different results if it weren't extremely disheartening and frustrating. This isn't how you teach. Clearly we were not properly prepared.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was my gateway course to learning how to study efficiently to best prepare for exams in college. As an applied science, chemistry cannot be learned by memorization alone and requires significant practice in comprehending problems based on foundational concepts and understanding the purpose of the given information in solving for the answer. As a first-generation and low-income student, it was extremely difficult to catch up initially, especially given I had never been taught how to properly study for standardized exams from a Title I school. I managed to do progressively better in this course by doing lots of practice problems to reinforce key concepts, consistently attending lectures and office hours, and most of all, proactively seeking additional academic resources, such as learning consultations with ARC or SAGE Tutoring.

Finally, I learned that chemistry is more than just chemistry, it is the study of life through path and state fns! question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cox, Dr. Liu, and Dr. Martinez left a lot to be desired from this course. While I applaud the incredible work of the TAs to fill in the gaps in teaching and caring, this course instruction was well below my expectations. The professors exhibited an overwhelming lack of empathy and care for students, instead opting to increase workload and shame those struggling. I am particularly disappointed in their reaction to most students struggling on Exam 1, which initially had an average score in the low 50s. Rather than recognizing that group failure likely indicated poor teaching on their part, they chose to complain that we all weren't trying hard enough. They offered for us to take the exact same test with the exact same resources a second time, which would be an almost comedic example of trying the same thing and expecting different results if it weren't extremely disheartening and frustrating. This isn't how you teach. Clearly we were not properly prepared.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first large lecture class. I learned how to navigate accessing different resources- whether it was TAs, office hours, or my peers- in order to succeed in this type of environment. I also gained a solid basis in general chemistry that prepares for for organic chemistry, as well as good experience in the laboratory setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped to develop my understanding of real world applications of chemistry such as with the Haber Bosch process (fertilizer synthesis). It helped me understand the research/foundations behind chemical formulas. It also taught me that practice is king for chemistry classes.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed a stronger ability to solve complex problems and apply my learning to them even if it was not something I had exactly seen before.
2. I developed strong study methods, finding an optimal balance between reviewing the material and practicing it. 
3. I gained insight into complex topics of chemistry such as molecular orbitals, and acids and bases at a high level of complexity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course values an analysis of inorganic chemistry at the microscopic level. Phenomena throughout the course are examined for their macroscopic value, but are never explained without looking into the chemical minutia that drive their behavior. This is most impactful through molecular orbital theory, which is covered in remarkable detail for the level of the course. I learned thermodynamic reasoning for the solubility of salts and the Haber-Bosch process, how to draw molecular orbital diagrams of hybridized molecules, basic physics regarding quantum phenomena, and how to characterize acid and base strength by molecular stability of their conjugate molecules.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Titration, Galvanic Cells, Electron Chemistry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to properly take a course in college. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned numerical awareness, advanced analysis of chemical structures, and expanded my ability to understand topics as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned about how scientific models were used to understand the chemical interactions around us (and to question the assumptions and limitations of those scientific models).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained deeper conceptual knowledge, including molecular orbital diagrams, transition metals, acid-base equilibria (emphasis on polyprotic acids), etc. I learned about the nature of models and the importance of history (e.g., famous figures). I learned to think beyond routine problem patterns and apply conceptual topics to more complex questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How atomic structure, bonding, and periodic trends shape chemical behavior and reactions
2. Learned to apply logical, step-by-step methods to approach and solve quantitative and qualitative chemistry problems
3. Cultivated a mindset of analyzing reactions, data, and systems from a chemical perspective, focusing on both the "how" and the "why" behind processes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Beyond the general chemistry topics, we went into acid/bases in a bit more depth than 101 & MO's. Honestly if you brush up on AP Chemistry you should be fine.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned is molecular orbitals, which was the hardest concept I learned this entire course. It went far beyond simply understanding spdf orbitals, but knowing how they merge to create more complex sharing of electrons. Another thing I learned was the henderson-hasselbach equation which revolutionized the way I approached acid-base titration problems. Finally, I learned how acids and bases, solubility, and thermodynamics connects to cell potential.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In CHEM-110DL-001: Honors Chemistry, I developed key skills in quantitative problem-solving, lab techniques, and molecular thinking. I learned how to apply stoichiometry to solve chemical equations and calculate key quantities. The labs provided hands-on experience with techniques like titration and spectroscopy, reinforcing both data analysis and safety. Additionally, I gained a deeper understanding of molecular structures, which improved my ability to predict the properties of substances based on their atomic composition. These skills have strengthened my overall approach to scientific problem-solving.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Gooden was excellent. He is a phenomenal explainer of organic chemistry because he is able to simplify complex concepts so that they are understandable. Multiple explanation includes hand signs, molecular modeling kits, the whiteboard, and the ipad.  He was also very personable which made the entire class highly engaged. All of the content in the class was taught in class. This was not the case in chem 101 where learning was done through a reverse classroom model which was highly ineffective towards understanding. Dr. Gooden focused heavily on understanding these concepts so that they are replicable on exam questions. The provided lecture notes, practice problem sets and practice exams directly reflected what the exams looked like-- there were no surprises on the exam. This gave me confidence during exams. He has been my best lecturer at Duke!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Gooden always stayed after class to answer everyone's questions -- even if this meant staying for a considerable amount of time. In addition to all of this, Gooden provided a very very substantial amount of practice problems through his discussions, problem sets, practice exams, and in-class examples. I genuinely can see the time and effort Gooden has put into making this class successful over the years. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
The difficulty of combining so many concepts together makes this class very difficult. It's like a game of chess--there are baseline rules as to how things work, but after a certain point, the complexity of the reactions requires sheer pattern recognition. Being able to see random epoxide formations, ring cleavages, pi bond interactions, solvations of carbocations that stabilize one reaction mechanism compared to another, and other factors that affect the outcome of a reaction requires doing a lot of problems. 
This class could be more intellectually stimulating if there were a greater list of challenge mechanism questions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a good introduction to organic chemistry. It requires a lot of effort outside of class, and will take up a lot of time throughout the semester if you aim for a good grade.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: GO TO OFFICE HOURS. I learned much more in office hours than I ever did in lecture. Preview the content before lecture (read the textbook, watch videos, whatever works best for you). If you go in with no background on lecture days you will probably not be able to follow everything as she goes very quickly and assumes you've studied the content before the lecture. Start studying >1 week in advance for midterms and use the practice exams she gives you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's difficult, but it's very manageable if you use your resources well. Do not just show up to lecture or discussion unprepared and expect to understand anything. If you read the textbook beforehand, you'll have a much better idea of what's going on, and the course will be far more enjoyable. Go to office hours and ask the professor questions if you have any confusion. Organic chemistry has a reputation of being hard, and while if you don't take it seriously it is difficult, if you respect the class and practice regularly you'll do just fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to largely teach yourself the information on your own. The material is not very hard, but there is a lot of it so don't do what I did (procrastinate learning the material), and stay on top of reading the textbook. The lectures are only helpful if you have read the material before coming to class, otherwise, they are pointless to attend. The practice tests are essential to doing good in class, so use them wisely and don't waste them. Lectures are also helpful for the occasional practice questions. If you can't learn the material on your own either utilize the TA office hours or wait to take it with a different professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- read the textbook but also use online resources to supplement when you are confused!!
- go to office hours
- stay on top of the readings, don't fall behind

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say first, they probably need a solid foundation on basic inorganic chemistry. Second, reviewing the content before each lecture is really necessary. Personally, I crammed to review the reactions before the third midterm and it was both time-consuming and difficult to memorize all of them within a couple of days. Finally, pre-read the textbook before each lecture can help you make use of lecture time because the professor will skip many "not important" topics to save time to cover more content. However, some of the topics that are not fully elaborate in lecture are useful when learning new concepts in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very challenging and difficult and requires a lot of independent self learning capabilities. It is expected that you review over the materials while having a 50% comprehension before coming to class, where you get your understanding slowly reinforced. I highly recommend making the most use of your time in office hours and get all of your questions answered as soon as possible. Also take advantage of discussion time. Going over the problem set is also extremely helpful with enhancing understanding. Finally, take full advantage of the 3 practice exams that she gives out before every test--pace yourself when taking them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Stay slightly ahead of everything. That way, when you inevitably have trouble on a topic, you can ask it in class when she's actually teaching it. Class feels like it's meant to be a check to see if you're understanding things, and to get familiar with her style of questions and perspective of organic chemistry. In office hours, she'll be able to go more in-depth with why she does certain things or how a mechanism works.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: good luck and study hard

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do a lot of problems from the textbook to build pattern recognition. Also, create notes for yourself based on question type (e.g., when you see this kind of question, then take these steps to avoid mistakes). It's very easy to try to do things in your head and mess it up. But at the same time no one was to be inefficient and waste time they don't need to. So, make sure to balance this by knowing what you should be writing/drawing out when doing a question.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is pretty hard. Even after reading the reviews, I convinced myself that it couldn't possibly be as difficult as everyone was saying it was, but they were right. Dr. Wang doesn't have empathy for students that perform poorly on her exams, and she makes you feel bad about not understanding a topic right away. If you want to or have to take organic chemistry with Prof Wang, be prepared.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Wang is a very nice person, and you can tell that she truly is passionate about organic chemistry as a subject. She is always willing to answer questions, and she responds to emails quickly. However, I would strongly advise against taking this course unless the rest of your courseload is relatively light. This course is the most difficult class that I have ever taken, and you will need to dedicate the majority of your time to it to avoid falling behind. There is so much content that it is impossible to cover all of it during lecture, so you will need to dedicate time to studying information both before and after lectures. Additionally, the labs can be relatively time consuming, so you will need to set aside time to complete those as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was the most intellectually stimulating course I have taken as a freshman. I learned so much about how different compounds/molecules interact with one another in a reaction form a whole new product. In a way, this class was like cooking but with organic molecules as the ingredients. One thing I learned is the naming of different organic molecules, which is a useful skill to have as it allows me to identify almost any compound I see based on just its structure. Another thing I learned is reactions between organic molecules. There is basically an infinite number of reactions that can take place, whether it be addition, radical, substitution, or elimination. Finally, I learned about stereochemistry which really allowed me to think about chemistry form a 3D point of view. The way molecules orient themselves in space are essential to understanding how they interact and how they are related to one another.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned so much about organic chemistry, from understanding reactions and solvents to delving into mechanisms and analyzing spectra data.
2. I learned how to advocate for myself. By regularly attending office hours and feeling comfortable asking questions when I didn’t understand something, I was able to quickly address challenges and strengthen my grasp of the material.
3. One of the most important lessons I took away from this course was the value of staying on top of the content. Everything builds on one another, and making sure I consistently practiced really helped solidify my understanding. That’s such a valuable lesson that I’ll carry with me in future courses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of responsibility and self accountability for this class. The amount of work you put into this class was really on you. It was up to you to decide how well you wanted to do and how much effort you were willing to give. In my opinion, this was my first real college class where I had a lot of freedom and independence. This was definitely a difficult adjustment but one that is so essential to my development as a student and an adult. I also learned so much on organic chemistry content in general. Although I took chem 110 before, the content is quite different. I learned how to time manage and plan my studying/ out of class time more efficiently.

response_text: Parise is great! He is super clear in his explanations and always willing to provide help! Definitely recommend taking this course with him!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is challenging but extremely rewarding—you must be willing to do the work and establish good study habits outside of the classroom. But once you are done, you will feel like you have learned a lot and grown as a student!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Work on problems!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do practice problems and stay on top of your work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Work hard and expect to invest in a humongous amount of time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It requires a lot of effort and practice but Dr. Parise is a great professor who is willing to meet with you.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: PRACTICE PRACTICE PRACTICE!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend they take this class! I would tell them that you do have to devote quite a bit of time to the class but it is worth it in the end! It might be discouraging to not get the scores they expected, but the what they should really be proud of is the amount of hardwork, dedication, and time they put into the class and that seeing an uphill trend in their grades is the real goal!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Practice a lot

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: it requires a lot of your attention, and if you can't give it that level of attention maybe take it on an offload semester or over the summer. But Dr. Parise is fantastic and you'll survive, collaborating with other students and just really learning those mechanisms will help you out so much!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Give ample time for yourself to practice and study. I regret not giving myself an extra day to let the info soak in, as it would've really helped.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are not premed ask yourself would you work as hard as people who have three Mickey Mouse classes and then spend all of their time on this class. Some interesting topics though.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The main drawback of this course is that the average is curved to the B-/B border, and you have to be a standard deviation above the average to get an A. The content is not super hard but it is difficult to do very well. There were often some exam questions that felt random (like strong bases on midterm 3).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: PRACTICE PROBLEMS!!!!!! The notes make organic chemistry super easy, but it only scratches the surface. In order to do well, you really need to put in the work and practice problems over and over until your face turns blue. It takes time and you won't understand it completely the first time around but don't be discouraged. Nothing good comes easy!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take organic with Parise. If you are committed to doing the practice problems he assigns and dedicate time to deeply understanding problems, the tests will not be hard. Thus, I would say the content of Orgo1 is not that challenging; it is more that you have to dedicate a lot of time for practice in order to succeed. Don't let the premed fearmongering scare you! Orgo with Parise is a very digestible class, but you just need to know how to study. Definitely a class to take with friends.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Try to take with a professor that emphasizes learning/mechanism over rote memorization.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely horrendous grading system. Your entire grade is based on the exams, so the pressure is always on when it's exam time. TAKE ANOTHER COURSE.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Parise is a great instructor who gives appropriately challenging exams the encourage the application of concepts rather than simple repetition and memorization. I highly recommend taking courses under his instruction if you hope to build valuable skills in organic chemistry.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Coming into this course, I imagined that it would be one of the hardest classes of my life--it's Orgo! However, Dr. Parise made this material so much easier to digest and learn--it really was not that bad. My recommendation is to take it as early as you can.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Watch videos about the topics before class, and do the textbook problems. U don't necessarily need to read the textbook but definitely do the problems, and come to lecture reviews if u can :D they make orgo wayy more fun.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Chem 201 is a difficult course. However, Professor McCafferty makes his lectures engaging and offers lots of resources to help you succeed. . The discussion sections in particular are very helpful, and joining a SAGE group helped me a lot. The practice problems and discussions problem sets are great study resources! Although I likely would not have taken this course if it were not a premed prerequisite, I ended up enjoying it far more than Gen Chem and found it an interesting topic. Expect a fair amount of memorization.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This term at the marine lab was the best learning environment I've experienced at Duke. It's really amazing to have a group thats all taking the same class, but also eating meals together, going to the beach, holding study groups, etc. We all supported each other through the class, and I was never stuck doing work feeling like I had nobody to ask for help. The marine lab really builds a community that translates so well into academic support. It really felt like everyone around me wanted me to learn and to help me to learn. Because Professor Canelas was our professor, discussion TA, lab TA, and grading TA, all in one, she knew exactly where we were at and how to help us. Being in such a small class compared to main campus, Professor Canelas could actually take the time to go back and reemphasize topics we were struggling on, answer specific questions, and work with us, rather than constantly needing to stick to a rigid schedule, hoping we keep up. Professor Canelas also held review sessions before tests/quizzes on Sunday nights that were so helpful (especially for calming nerves!)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Organic Chemistry is fascinating. When you put in the time and find people to study with, you will have more fun learning it. Good study strategies make all the difference.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely don’t fall behind and keep up with ruders on the day it was assigned if you work proactively the problems solved during class will be much more beneficial rather than “just looking back on it later” since then you’ve wasted more time being lost in class and now looking at your notes after class than what would’ve happened had you just learned what you were supposed to earlier. It’s very easy to just not follow the schedule so don’t fall into the trap.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I really enjoyed this class, and I think the marine lab is the best place to take it. It’s a hard class but you don’t have to balance other classes with it, and I found that the condensed schedule made it easier to learn since I can have a hard time retaining things over longer periods of time during fall/spring semesters. The marine lab is also a super fun place to be and the community is really great.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend that students stay on top of there work and sometimes even do Ruder workbook assignments ahead of time, especially if taken during the summer. This allows them to have more time to learn the initial information and have any questions they may have answered during actual lecture. This way, the new information is also reinforced throughout lecture since it is the second explanation of it you  see.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to not understand concepts during lecture and do a lot of self-teaching on your own time. Studying with others also helps a lot! Overall, because this class is the only thing you are taking during the six weeks, the stress/work levels I would imagine to be pretty reasonable/comparable to taking this same class, uncondensed, on main campus.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: DO IT! Taking it at the marine lab specifically has been such an enriching experience. This has definitely been one of the most interesting and unique experiences I have had at Duke and I am grateful for it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Having taken CHEM-201 both at Duke’s main campus during a regular semester and at the Marine Lab during a summer session, I STRONGLY recommend that students planning to take organic chemistry consider taking the course during a summer term at the Marine Lab.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is going to be difficult just because it's orgo but I think taking it in the summer by itself was definitely helpful as I didn't have to switch focus between multiple classes. The instructor is funny and keeps you engaged. It was such a small class that it was very easy to ask questions and often the instructor was willing to alter structure of a lecture based on what students asked for.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
- Be prepared to dedicate a significant amount of your time and energy to studying Orgo! Don't forget that this is something you're choosing to spend your summer doing, and while it's okay that you may "dread" it, it can be (or just is) an enjoyable and intellectually stimulating course! 
- take advantage of the facilities and natural environment around you to spend any free time you have 
- practice, practice, practice! Sometimes, it can be difficult to understand WHY something works (highly recommend OrganoMech for that), but being able to familiarise yourself with the mechanism of a reaction and what happens often leads you to better answer questions you previously had

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I absolutely 100% recommend taking orgo at the marine lab. Taking orgo in a block schedule format allows you the time to really understand the content without being overwhelmed by other classes. Despite being only 6 weeks, the class doesn't feel rushed at all and you definitely aren't overwhelmed by class time (3-4 hours a day but its very well split up with breaks and only a 4 day week.) Professor Canelas really emphasized that she wanted us to get the full experience of spending the summer at the marine lab, encouraging us to take breaks, go to the beach, watch dolphins, etc. and that really helped us all to not get burnt out. Orgo is hyped up to be a really hard class, and it is, but this format makes it super manageable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked everything about the structure of this class. The lecture on Monday of strict information and then 2 other days of working through problems with peers allowed me to essentially get a one-on-one tutor feel during class time which helped to learn material much faster. This class sets you up amazingly for success and dependent on how much work you put in, you can succeed. I actually had a good amount of chemistry experience in high school but felt unsure of how well I would do in a chem course in college, so I last minute decided to take 99D instead of 101 and am so glad I did. I probably could have done okay in 101 going straight in because I had chem experience in high school, and I still struggled to relearn basic concepts that all my teachers always assumed we knew but were never formally taught. It is so nice for Dr. Canelas and Anna to go fully in depth in explaining basic concepts that are never really taught in detail, at least in my experience, and they never make you feel stupid for asking "easy" to answer questions and in fact encourage more questions. I have talked to so many students in this class that had barely any chem experience in hs and are extremely grateful for having this opportunity to learn they didn't have in hs.

response_text: The professor has so many resources available to students that if you perform badly, it honestly is not anyone's fault but your own.
